Hey great work! I just have a quick question for you. How would you create a light painting photograph with a subject in it, and keep that subject tact sharp without any blur? Is it possible? I know your shots show subjects in it but I don't want any blur from my subject. The only thing that makes sense to me is 1 of 2 ways: 1) Photoshop 2 separate exposure and make a composite. Although I feel that this may look fake. 2) use a ttl chord, (10m or longer) put the camera on 2nd curtain, paint the shot and the flash will freezing any blur. But with this I feel like the subject might get that ghosty faded effect.

Let me know what you think!

Red, Green and Blue make White.

Wait. Aren't the primary colours red, yellow and blue? That's at least the primary colours of a common colour chart. Is this just a mix up between art and science, because the eye can see red, green and blue, but somehow in art the primary colours are described as red, yellow and blue because of the colour circle? Because this is the first time I've ever heard someone (that's smart) say that green is a primary colour. And sorry if you get annoyed when I write colour, I use English UK and not US.
Vsauce did a video on this. Google: "vsauce this is not yellow" and you'll find it.

Well, sort of.  Your eyes can only see red, green, and blue, so when you see something "yellow", it's because the red and green cones (sensors) in your eyes are both responding.  That could be because the light is actually yellow (such as from a rainbow or yellow light bulb), or because you're seeing a mixture of red and green (like from a TV or computer screen).

@destinws2 You should do a video explaining the color wheel and color theory, and how the primaries people are taught in kindergarten (red, blue, yellow) should actually be Cyan, Yellow, and Magenta--the subtractive "complements" of the the additive primaries (Cyan is opposite Red, Yellow is opposite blue, Magenta is opposite Green on the color wheel). This makes sense because Cyan = Blue + Green = White - Red, etc. I hope this made sense. You can PM me if you would like clarification.
